text:
A while ago, a website talked about the dangers of telling everyone online where you are. The website said that when you say, "Hey, I'm here," you are also telling everyone, even people you don't know, that you are not at home. This made people think about the problems of sharing too much online. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with many people. This can be exciting because it might bring us money or fame. So, we share our secrets, photos, and stories online. But later, we might find out that this is not safe, and we can get lost in it. 

In the early days of the internet, some people tried sharing their lives online. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with being famous before social media existed. These people were the first bloggers. They learned lessons that we can learn from today. 

In 1994, a student named Justin Hall started sharing his life online. He wrote about everything and posted photos and art. In 1996, he started a daily blog. Many people read it because he shared so much. But one day, he stopped because he fell in love, and his partner said, "It's me or the blog." He learned that sharing too much online can make people not trust you.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong had a blog where she sometimes wrote about her job. Someone at her work shared her blog with her bosses, and she lost her job. This shows that what we say online can affect our real lives. But Heather's story ended well. She got married, started blogging again about her family, and now her blog helps support her family. She learned to be careful about what she shares online.

The internet lets us say anything, but that doesn't mean we should say everything.

Some time ago, scientists started talking about a movie called "What the Bleep Do We Know?" This movie mixes real facts and stories to show that there is a lot about our universe we do not understand. Scientists usually agree with this idea because no one knows everything about the universe. However, some scientists were worried about the movie and said it was bad or even dangerous. 

At first, the movie seemed normal. Scientists talked about how new things we learn make the universe seem stranger than we thought. But then, the movie talked about strange ideas, like water changing because of people's thoughts. A Japanese researcher said that happy thoughts could make water look nice, and bad thoughts could make it look ugly. The movie showed pictures of ice crystals to prove this. Some people found this interesting, but many scientists did not believe it. They wanted better proof.

The movie's ideas were not strange enough. Scientists have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and is growing because of something called "dark energy." This is real and comes from many years of research. Scientists also found that our brains take a little time to understand what we see, and they have learned where modern humans came from. Some scientists think there is a link between life on Earth and the universe's design.

Science is not finished. We still have a lot to learn. Some things in nature might never be fully understood. Scientists are trying to create a "Theory of Everything" to explain all the forces and particles in the universe. Many people think the universe is amazing.

I like writing novels and short stories. Writing novels is hard, like planting a forest. Writing short stories is fun, like planting a garden. Both are important to me. Trees in the forest give shade, and flowers in the garden bring bees and butterflies. I write novels and short stories at different times. When I finish a novel, I write short stories. When I finish short stories, I write a novel. I started writing short stories in 1984. It was hard at first, but I enjoyed it. My first short story was 'Breaking Waves'. Short stories are quick to write, usually about a week. Novels take a long time, maybe a year or two. Short stories can come from small ideas, like a word or picture. If a short story is not good, it's okay. Even famous writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver did not always write perfect stories. I learn from my short stories to help me write better novels. Short stories are like small memories for me. They show my feelings, and I like sharing them with readers.

Science is a way to understand the world. It helps us in many ways, like curing diseases. Science can be hard to understand, and sometimes people do not agree about it. Scientists often change their ideas when they learn new things. This book talks about big ideas in science that changed how we think. 

Science is always changing. One scientist might say something, and another might prove it wrong. Sometimes, these changes are small, but sometimes they are big and change what we believe. For example, a long time ago, people thought the universe was like a big clock. Later, scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein found new ideas that changed this view.

Science has given us many new things, like X-rays and the idea of the Big Bang. Some people think we might soon understand everything about the universe, but we are not sure yet. Science is important because it helps us control nature, but we must be careful. We need to understand science because it affects our lives and the future of our planet.

Around 2015, big book companies noticed that ebook sales stopped growing or even went down. This made people wonder if ebooks would be important in the future. Some people thought ebooks were a big deal and spent too much money on them. But, both ebooks and print books can exist together. People still ask if ebooks will replace print books. This idea makes us think and talk a lot. 

Why do we think ebooks and print books are fighting? This is because we feel excited and scared about new things. In the past, people thought new technology would replace old ones. For example, when TV came, people thought radio would disappear, but it didnâ€™t. Radio found new ways to be useful, like in cars. 

The idea of books disappearing is not new. In 1894, people thought phonographs would replace books with audiobooks. Many times, people thought new things like movies, radio, and smartphones would end print books. Some people worried this would be bad for culture, while others thought ebooks were great. 

When new technology comes, we feel mixed emotions. We love and fear change because we have strong feelings for things like books and TVs. We even name our cars or get mad at our computers. New technology makes us change how we feel about these things. 

As technology changes, we miss what we used to have. This is why people like old things. For example, when printing started in the 15th century, people wanted old handwritten books. When movies got sound, people missed silent films. The same happened with photos and music records. 

E-readers made people like old books more, even their smell. This shows print books might not disappear. But the idea of things disappearing helps us understand change. We use stories about endings to make sense of new things. These stories show our excitement for the future and our fear of losing what we know.

For a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30 every weekday. I brushed my teeth, made coffee, and wrote about how famous people from the past 400 years did their best work. I wanted to know how they found time each day to be creative and productive. I looked at their daily lives, like when they slept, ate, and worked. I wanted to show how their habits made them who they were.

The book I wrote is called "Daily Rituals." It talks about people's routines. Routines are the things we do every day without thinking much. A good routine can help us use our time and energy better. The psychologist William James said that having good habits can help us focus on important things. But he himself found it hard to stick to a schedule.

I got the idea for this book one Sunday afternoon. I was at work, trying to write a story, but I kept getting distracted. I started looking online for how other writers worked. I found many interesting stories and thought someone should collect them. So, I started a blog called "Daily Routines" and later wrote this book.

In the book, I share many people's routines. I used quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. I also used information from biographies and articles. I thank all the writers and researchers whose work helped me. You can find all my sources in the Notes section of the book.

Howard became a palaeontologist because of something that happened when he was six years old. His family could not go on holiday to Spain because it was too expensive. Instead, they went to the English coast. There, Howard found a fossil called an ammonite on the beach. This made him want to study fossils. 

At university, Howard decided he wanted to study very old fossils, not dinosaurs. He liked studying small, ancient creatures in rocks. After finishing his studies, he worried about finding a job. He knew he was good, but getting a job was not easy.

Howard applied for a job at Tavistock College in London. On the day of his interview, the professor who liked another candidate could not come. Another professor, who did not like the first professor, helped Howard get the job. Howard was happy to get the job, even though he knew it was not because he was the best.

Howard liked his job because he could plan his work. But sometimes, unexpected things happened. One day, someone stole his briefcase with important notes. He was upset but went for coffee with a colleague. There, he met a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. The visitor told him about a new collection of fossils. Howard decided to study these fossils. He changed his plans and decided to go to Nairobi instead of other trips. This new project was very important for his career.

Charles Spence will eat almost anything. He is a Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. At home, he has ice cream made from bee larvae. It looks like maggots but tastes a bit nutty and floral. Spence and his team study how we taste food. They want to make eating bugs normal. They also study how our senses work together to change how we taste food. Spence helps big food companies and famous restaurants with his research. He studies things like who we eat with, how food looks, and even the noise around us. All these things can change how food tastes.

Spence wrote a book called "The Perfect Meal" with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman. It has many interesting facts about eating. For example, the first person to order food in a group enjoys their meal the most. Also, we eat more when we are with other people. Spence's lab in Oxford is simple and not high-tech. He works with cooks who cannot pay for research. A big food company gives him money for his work. In the past, people thought this kind of research was not real science. But now, it is important because it shows how research can help people.

Spence helps food companies reduce salt and sugar in their products. They do it slowly so people do not notice the change. If people know about the change, they might not like the taste. Spence met Heston Blumenthal, a famous chef, while working on a project. Together, they created a dish called "Sound of the Sea" that uses sound to change how food tastes. Spence found that high-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, and low-pitched music makes it taste bitter. An airline will soon use music to match the food they serve. A brand also made an app that plays music while ice cream softens.

At home, Spence has fun dinner parties. Once, they ate rabbit with fur on the cutlery. Another time, they used colored lights and sounds with drinks. For Spence, home and work are the same. He loves to explore how we taste food everywhere.

Our brains are very busy today. We get a lot of information, some true and some not. We have to decide what is important and what is not. We also do more things by ourselves now. In the past, travel agents helped us book flights, and salespeople helped us in shops. Now, we do these things on our own. We try to do many things at once, like work, family, hobbies, and watching TV. Our smartphones help us do this. But there is a problem. We think we can do many things at the same time, but we cannot. Earl Miller, a brain expert, says our brains are not good at doing many things at once. We just switch quickly from one thing to another, and this is not good for us. It makes us less efficient. Doing many things at once can make us stressed and confused. Our brains like new things, so we get distracted easily. Just having the chance to do many things at once can make us less smart. Glenn Wilson, a psychology expert, says trying to focus when you have an unread email can make you less smart. Russ Poldrack, another brain expert, found that learning while doing other things makes the information go to the wrong part of the brain. If students do homework and watch TV, the schoolwork goes to a part of the brain for skills, not facts. Without TV, it goes to a part of the brain that helps us remember better. Making decisions is also hard for our brains. Even small decisions can make us tired and lead to bad choices. Many people say email is a big problem because there is too much of it. A friend's son said his dad just answers emails all day, and his dad agreed. We feel we must reply to emails, but it is hard to do that and do other things too.

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino broke concrete at night to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In the US, female bats help other bats give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, people did not think these questions were important. Scientists studied animal actions and results, but not their feelings. But now, things are changing. Scientists are starting to study animal emotions. Books like "Wild Justice" and "Do Fish Feel Pain?" talk about this. There is a big question: do animals have feelings like humans? Another question is about right and wrong. In one study, cows opened a gate to get food. Cows that opened the gate themselves were happier than those that got help. If cows like solving problems, what does this mean for eating beef? Some people, like Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, think we should stop eating meat. He says this is a big change, like when slavery ended. Professor Aubrey Manning thinks we should think again about how smart animals are. He says animals have a simpler mind than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail says we should not think animals are like humans. The main issue is not just science or morals, but philosophy. Can we know what it is like to be a bat? Balcombe talks about an experiment with birds called starlings. Some starlings lived in nice cages, others in bad ones. When given bad food, only the birds in nice cages ate it. Balcombe thinks the birds in bad cages felt sad. He believes we will one day see animal rights like we see human rights. Professor Manning agrees with Balcombe. He says ideas about animals change over time. It is a difficult topic, and people have strong opinions.

Text: Critical thinking is a way to understand what we read or hear better. Adrian West, a researcher, says that people think arguing helps find the truth. Technology helps us store and process information, but it might change how we solve problems. We see a lot of bad thinking and opinions, which can confuse us. More data does not always mean more knowledge. Reading books has gone down, and this might hurt critical thinking. People focus more on quick media and doing many things at once. We don't know exactly how technology affects thinking. Computers and the internet can be good or bad for thinking. Some games help with thinking, but too many links on the internet can stop deep thought. Reading helps imagination and thinking more than video games and TV. Visual media can help with some information, but they don't give time to think deeply. Many young people don't use their full abilities. How we see technology affects how we think about critical thinking. Video games can be good for learning, says James Paul Gee. Games like Sim City teach decision-making and thinking skills. In the digital age, we need to understand how technology affects thinking.

Matthew Crawford is a writer and a motorcycle mechanic. He used to work in an office but did not like it. He wrote a book about how working with your hands is good. His new book talks about how to live in the modern world. He got the idea when he saw ads on a credit card machine while shopping. He thinks these ads make it hard for us to focus on what we want to think about. 

Crawford says we are losing the ability to think and remember because we are always interrupted. We don't talk to strangers anymore because we want to avoid these interruptions. We see the world through things like video games and phone apps, which can control us. 

Many people are worried about this. For example, some people complain about emails but still check them all the time. Studies show that just seeing a phone can distract us. We are more aware of other things we could be doing. 

Crawford believes technology makes us focus too much on ourselves. We prefer texting to talking because it feels safer. This can make us lose real connections with people. 

He gives an example from his gym. Before, there was one music player for everyone, which sometimes caused problems. Now, people listen to their own music with earphones, so the gym is less social. 

Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we should have rules to reduce noise and distractions in public places. Second, we should do activities that make us focus on real things, like cooking or playing sports. These activities help us connect with the world and other people. 

By focusing on one thing, we can learn to pay better attention to everything else.

Text: "What do you do for work?" is a common question. We often talk about our jobs. But for me, as a philosopher, it's a bit tricky. Saying "I am a philosopher" can sound like I think I know more than others, which is not true. Philosophers are just like everyone else. 

People think philosophers are special because they talk about life and thinking. A long time ago, a Greek philosopher named Aristotle said thinking about life is the best way to live. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said we should think about our lives to make them better. 

Thinking about life doesn't mean you have to read a lot of books. It means looking at your life and making sure it is good. You don't have to be away from people to do this. It's about sharing ideas and making life better for everyone.

Today, philosophy can seem far from real life. Many philosophers write for other experts, not for everyone. This makes it hard for people to understand what philosophers do. 

I work in ethics, which is about deciding if actions are right or wrong. But philosophy is more than just this. It helps us think about our actions and beliefs. By doing this, we can learn and improve our lives.

Text: People who love food, like chefs and food lovers, think a lot about what we eat and how we eat. In the past, philosophers talked about food to explain other ideas, like learning. Sometimes, they talked about food, but it was really about other things. 

Epicurus, a Greek philosopher, talked about enjoying life and avoiding pain. People now think of him when they think about enjoying food and drink. His name is used in restaurants and food shops because it makes people think the food is special.

Food is important in our culture and society. It comes from history and is shared with others. We eat with friends and family, and food is grown and shared in our communities. We talk about food a lot because it is a big part of our lives.

Some people write about food and taste. They are not special experts; they are just good at describing food. Most studies about how we see and taste focus on vision, not taste, and this should change.

Food can be beautiful, like art or music. But when we eat food, it is gone, unlike when we look at a painting or listen to music. Some people think food should be part of art discussions, but others say it cannot be because it does not last.

There are also questions about what we should eat, like organic or vegetarian food. These choices show what we believe is right or wrong. Philosophers ask why we make these choices.

Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. At home, we cook for family and friends, and everyone is welcome. In restaurants, chefs cook for their job, and only trained people work in the kitchen.

Food can help people from different cultures understand each other. We can learn about other cultures by eating their food and making friends while eating together. This has been important in international meetings for a long time. A recent essay talks about how food helps people connect, with many fun stories to explain this idea.

Rob Daviau is from the US and makes special board games called 'legacy' games. He thought old board games were not fun or hard enough. So, he wanted to change them. He made a new version of a game called Risk. In this new game, what you do in one game can change the next game. You might have to tear up cards or change the board. The game has a story that goes on for many sessions. 

Rob also helped make a legacy version of another game called Pandemic. In this game, players work together to stop diseases. His next game was SeaFall, where players explore new lands. Making these games is hard because designers have to think about all the choices players might make. They test the games a lot to make sure they work well.

At first, Rob thought only a few people would like legacy games. But many people loved them. They think these games are exciting and new. One fan, Ben, said itâ€™s like watching a new movie every time. Legacy games are like TV shows with episodes. Rob wanted to tell stories with games, like writing a book. He is happy to see others try new things with his idea. Some people think legacy games change how we think about board games.

Text: 'One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealandâ€™s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and went into a small drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online. People like stories about animals escaping, like rats and llamas, because it makes us think animals are like us. Octopuses are very smart, even though they look very different from us. They can open jars, recognize faces, and use coconut shells as armor. Some people think it is not scientific to say animals are like humans. But Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas, says it is wrong to ignore the human-like traits of animals. He calls this "anthropodenial." He says animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, and understanding others. In the past, people thought animals were smart. In medieval times, animals could even be put on trial for crimes. Charles Darwin, who created the theory of evolution, said the difference between humans and animals is not big. In the 20th century, people started to see animals as machines that only respond to rewards and punishments. But now, Dr. de Waal believes we are starting to see animals as smart again. He says we are learning more about animal intelligence. The best tests for animal intelligence consider what each animal is good at. For example, squirrels can remember where they hide nuts, even if they are not good at human memory tasks. In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, Sy Montgomery says if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might think we are not smart because we cannot change the color of our skin. Dr. de Waal is not sure if Inky really found his way to the ocean, but he knows stories like this help people appreciate animal intelligence. He did an experiment with monkeys to see if they feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers and others got grapes, the monkeys with cucumbers got upset. A video of this experiment convinced many people that animals can feel emotions like envy.'

Robots were once only in science fiction stories, but now they are becoming very important. Robots have been used in car factories for a long time. Now, experts say robots will soon be used in many more places. Many people think robots will do most jobs in the next 50 years, but they also think their own jobs will stay the same. This is not true. Robots will change every job. 

For example, an Australian company made a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. This is much faster than two people can do in a day. Another company in San Francisco made a robot called Tally. Tally moves around supermarkets to check if items are on the shelves and priced correctly.

Some people say robots will create new jobs for people who can fix and program them. But others worry that robots will take away jobs that need people skills. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, says robots will work with people and other robots soon. In a few years, many big companies will have a special person in charge of robots. 

In five years, people working with robots will earn more money, but there will not be enough skilled workers for all the jobs. Dr. Zhang says people need to learn new skills because they cannot do the same job forever. New robots will also be made for homes and will be very smart. 

This change is a big chance for companies, but it also means we need new rules to keep us safe. Many jobs might be lost, so education is important. Countries need more people studying science, technology, engineering, and maths to stay strong in the future.

Text: George Mallory, a famous climber, was asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest. He said, "Because it's there." People often wonder why anyone would do something so dangerous. Some think climbing is about adventure and fun. 

In 1967, a writer named Tejada-Flores talked about different types of climbing. He said there are seven kinds of climbing, each with its own rules. For example, some climbs use a lot of equipment, and some use very little. This idea is popular among climbers today.

Many climbers love the feeling of freedom when they climb. But sometimes, climbing can feel limiting, like when a storm keeps you stuck in a tent. This is a bit of a puzzle, but some say the simple life of a climber is a kind of freedom.

Joe Fitschen, a US climber, thinks we should ask, "Why do people climb?" He believes climbing is in our nature. We like to take on challenges, even if they are risky.

Brian Treanor, a US academic, says climbing can teach us important things like courage and respect for nature. He thinks these are important in today's world.

Some climbers believe that climbing without help from others or technology is better. Ebert and Robinson, two expert climbers, think these climbs deserve more respect. But this idea can be dangerous because it might make people take unnecessary risks.

Climbing is also about being in the moment and solving problems. Some people say climbing is like Zen philosophy, which helps train the mind to find peace. This is another reason why people might be drawn to climbing.

Alfred Brendel was a famous pianist for over 60 years. He played and recorded many important piano pieces. He did not teach much. People who knew him well saw he could be fun, but he was serious in concerts. He worked hard, always studying, traveling, and playing music.

One day, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to Brendel after a concert and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not want to teach him. He thought, "You don't need a mountain guide to teach a child to walk." But Kit, who was 14, played very well. Brendel listened to him and thought, "I have to make time for him." Kit played beautifully and had a special way of understanding music.

Now, Kit is 19 and learning many things. He studies languages, math, and plays tennis. He also writes music. Brendel says it is important to write music to understand it better. Kit has a great memory and listens well. He can do what Brendel teaches him.

Brendel is careful not to say Kit will be a great pianist too soon. He thinks it is not good to expect too much too early. Brendel is now 80 years old and does not play in public anymore. He is happy with what he has done in his life and still thinks about music.

When I was a child, I thought gardens were beautiful places. My grandad's garden was not in a dirty city. It was next to a river and went down to the water. You couldn't touch the river, but you could hear the water and birds. I thought all gardens were like this â€“ quiet and peaceful. Grandad's garden was simple. He didn't have a greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old windows with plastic patches.

At home, my dad was often quiet. He liked funny things and had favorite phrases like "It's immaterial to me," which means "I don't mind." He left school without finishing and became a plumber. He didn't love plumbing; it was just his job. He and my mom once thought about moving to Canada, but they didn't. He was good at fixing things at home, like making bookshelves.

My parents moved house only once. My mom liked to change furniture. One day, we got a piano. I wanted to like it, but it scared me. I liked the brass candlesticks on it, but my mom took them away. My sister got piano lessons, not me. When I asked why, my mom said, "You'd never have practiced."

I liked the river best. I would go there with a fishing net and old sandals. I looked for fish to catch and take home. After trying to keep them alive, I put them back in the river.

I wanted to leave school early, but it seemed hard. One day, my dad said, "There's a job for an apprentice gardener. You might like it." He thought I should be a carpenter, but he saw I loved gardening. I think he hoped it would be good for me.

Lawrence MacEwen is on his island, the Isle of Muck, in Scotland. The wind is very strong, but Lawrence is not worried. He is with his sheepdog, Tie. Lawrence is showing me the islands around us. He points and says, "That island is Eigg. The one next to it is the Isle of Rum. It rains a lot there." I see the rain on Rum's mountains. "Beyond Rum is the island of Soay," he says.

Lawrence has to move his sheep, so we walk down the hill. He tells me about the island. Muck is three kilometers long and half as wide. The geese eat a lot of grass. The MacEwen family has lived here for 3000 years. While moving the sheep, Tie, the dog, is not doing well. Lawrence tells Tie to go right, but Tie goes straight. Lawrence is not happy with Tie.

The Isle of Muck is run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence and his wife, Jenny, run the farm. Their son, Colin, takes care of the cottages. Their daughter, Mary, and her husband, Toby, run the island hotel. Mary and Toby like that their children can play outside safely.

Life on the island is different. Electricity is not always on. My first night, I wait for the lights. In the morning, Mary makes breakfast with a torch. There is no mobile phone service, but you can get it on a hill. Most people stop using their phones after a few days.

The boat brings groceries and three musicians to the island. They play music in the tearoom, and everyone enjoys it. That night, Lawrence tells me how he met Jenny. Her father bought a farm on the Isle of Soay without seeing it. Jenny went to manage it, even though she only had typing skills.

It rains a lot, but the food is good. Mary sends me to get fresh fish from Sandy Mathers. We eat the fish for dinner, and it is very tasty. The next morning, I need to take a ferry to another island. Many ferries were canceled before because of bad weather. If my ferry does not come, I will stay on Muck for two more days, which I secretly hope for.

Text: 'The video game industry used to be small and mostly for young people. Now, it is very important and growing. Making video games is hard work. It needs many people and a lot of time. Jim Donelly, who works for a games magazine, says it is hard to get a job in big companies. But the industry needs more game designers. Not just the big bosses, but also people who make small parts of games. To get into the industry, you should make your own games. You need to show what you can do. John Field, another expert, says it is not easy. Many people want to work in games, but not everyone has the skills. A good course in games can help. Most game designers start as programmers or artists. They like all kinds of entertainment and art. They are not just fans; they want to make games better. Knowing people in the industry can also help you get a job. Video games are not just for kids anymore. Families play together, and there are many games on phones and social media. John thinks there are many chances to grow in this industry. Games are fun and can help people learn new things.'

Text: 'Since I was a child, I always wanted to play football. My dad liked football too and he helped me play. He didn't force me, and I am happy about that. I had a friend who came to the park with us. His dad was very strict and always said, â€˜You canâ€™t do this, you canâ€™t do that.â€™ My friend stopped playing football because of this. I am glad my dad was not like that. When I score a great goal, people say it is luck, but it is not. I practiced a lot since I was a kid. The best players practice for many years. Sometimes young players bump into each other, but I learned good skills. When I teach kids, I tell them to enjoy learning. I played many sports at school like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know school is important, but I only thought about football then. The teachers were good, but I didnâ€™t notice. I donâ€™t want this for my son. We read him books, but he is too young to sit still. He likes to kick the books, like me. At the start of my football career, the manager helped young players like me. He didnâ€™t make a big deal about it. We knew we had to prove ourselves. I scored in the first game, but we lost. A TV presenter said, â€˜You canâ€™t win anything with kids.â€™ This made us work harder. I trust my friends and family a lot. Having a lot of money can be hard. People say, â€˜Why does your mother still work?â€™ I help my parents with money. I paid for their house and bought them a car. My family is strong and they like to work. My mum is a hairdresser and she loves her job. I like to help people around me with my money. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think. After I stop playing football, I want to take a year off. I want to go skiing, but I canâ€™t now. If I break my leg skiing, I canâ€™t play football and I wonâ€™t have insurance.'

Sam Carter helped us find a place to live at Reef Point. Sam was my dad's agent in Los Angeles. My dad couldn't write in Los Angeles, so Sam found us a cheap place to stay. Reef Point was quiet in the summer because of the sea fogs. People didn't visit much because the road was bad, and a nicer place, La Carmella, was nearby. Only people with no money or who loved surfing came to Reef Point. But when the weather got hot, many people came. My dad was busy writing a script and didn't notice me much. I spent time on the beach with my dog, Rusty. Rusty wasn't our dog at first, but he stayed with us. I gave him water, and my dad didn't mind him much. Rusty liked to dig and bring me things, sometimes things that weren't his. I had to give those back to their owners. Rusty also liked to swim with me, even though I was faster. One day, after swimming, we watched surfers. One surfer was really good. She came over and talked to me. She asked why I didn't surf, and I said I didn't have a board or money. She found out my dad wrote a book called "Tall as the Morning." She was interested when she heard that. People were always more interested when they knew about my dad's book.

Violet Hetherington was in a long line at the dock in Southampton. She was waiting to get on the ship called Queen Caroline. Her friend Annie had told her to arrive late to avoid waiting, but this advice was wrong. There was a problem with the computer system, and everyone had to wait. People were upset because they paid a lot for the trip and wanted it to be nice.

Violet wanted to leave, but she realized she lost her phone. This made her feel even worse about the trip. She couldn't call the taxi company to check if she left her phone there because all her numbers were in the phone. Her son Harry always told her to be careful about this. She asked a couple behind her if she could use their phone. She called Harry and left a message asking him to ask her neighbor Kristina to look for her phone in her apartment.

Finally, the line started moving, and Violet gave her travel papers to get on the ship. She didn't like the ship's entrance because it looked like a hotel trying too hard to be fancy. There were shiny fake wood panels, big chandeliers, and carpets like those in airports. She took the elevator, which was crowded with tired people, to the twelfth floor. She was happy to find her room had a balcony, just like she wanted. She had paid a lot to make sure she could see the sea.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction, he did not know he was finding the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof wanted pictures for a book about Portage Park in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 pictures by Maier, a street photographer who took interesting photos. Maloof now has a big collection of Maierâ€™s work. In his home, he has her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, plus many movies and audiotapes. One morning, Maloof looked at all of it and felt lucky. â€˜When I bought this, I didnâ€™t know what it was,â€™ Maloof said. â€˜I could have sold it all to someone else.â€™ Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon are learning about Maierâ€™s life. They talked to families she worked for as a nanny and people from the shop where she developed film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and grew up in France. In 1951, she went back to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person and always had a camera. She wore big coats, hats, and strong shoes. â€˜On her day off, she had her camera and we didnâ€™t see her until late,â€™ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband hired Maier. â€˜She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.â€™ Maier knew a lot about theatre and movies. She was not very social but liked to take pictures of people and sometimes recorded them talking. She loved her â€˜second jobâ€™ of taking pictures. â€˜She was a true artist and did what she wanted,â€™ said Rydzon. â€˜She didnâ€™t let anything stop her.â€™ Maierâ€™s work was pure art; she didnâ€™t do it for money. Her photos often showed women, children, old people, and the poor. â€˜Vivianâ€™s pictures are very interesting,â€™ said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees other photographersâ€™ influence in her work and wonders if she made her own style. â€˜Was Vivian very skilled or did she copy others?â€™ Maloof wonders if he will see all the negatives, which he keeps in three big, safe cabinets. He was not interested in photography until he found Maierâ€™s work. Inspired by her photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. â€˜As I learned more, I saw her work was about people and street scenes,â€™ he said. â€˜There was more to her work than I thought. Now, we want people to know her name. We want Vivian Maier in history books.â€™

Text: 'When a book is called ambitious, it often means it didn't fully succeed. But this is not true for Eleanor Catton's book, The Luminaries. I talked to her in the UK when her book was very popular. She was calm, even though she was still in her twenties. She had just come from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She told me a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She showed her book to the officer. The officer asked, â€˜Whatâ€™s it about?â€™ This is not an easy question for a writer. The Luminaries is set in the 1860s in New Zealand. There are many crimes, and 12 men meet to solve them. The story is very complex. Catton wanted to write a murder mystery, not a history book, but she found the past gave her more ideas for her characters. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters enough attention. When I asked how it feels to be successful at a young age, she said it feels nice because people in her small country feel proud too. She said, â€˜What is annoying is when people think my book is not serious.â€™ She wanted to write the book like a spiral, with each part half the length of the one before. The book gets faster as it goes. I asked if it matters if readers notice this. She said, â€˜I wanted to make a book with patterns that donâ€™t matter, but if you care, you can see them.â€™ Even with its special structure, The Luminaries is an exciting murder mystery. She didnâ€™t plan the book before writing. She liked to write herself into difficult situations and then find a way out. She also wanted the book to be fun for readers. We talked about her love for TV drama series. I asked if she wants to write for TV. She said, â€˜That could be pretty cool.â€™ She is very excited when talking about writing and New Zealand. She said, â€˜When I come to Britain, my imagination changes because it is a different place. I see why writers leave New Zealand to be around more people.â€™ But for now, New Zealand is her home. I hope it gives her ideas for more books.'

Jonny Kinkead loved making things and playing the guitar when he was a boy. For the last 40 years, he has been making guitars by hand. He says, "I still love the guitar. It's amazing how two pieces of wood can make a beautiful sound. Different wood makes different sounds, and it still surprises me."

Jonny learned to play the guitar at age 11. At 16, he wanted a bass guitar. Instead of buying one, he decided to make it himself. He studied guitars to understand how their shape and wood type changed the sound. Jonny and his brothers used to build model boats and planes, so he knew how to make things. His father taught them how to use tools. Jonny also fixed instruments for his friends.

Jonny's first bass guitar was good, but he didn't think about making guitars as a job. He liked painting and sculpture too. After school, he studied architecture at university because he liked design. But he left the course because he wanted to do something different. He realized making guitars is like sculpture because you shape the sound. He thought it was better than art because people use guitars.

Jonny started making guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows to earn money. At first, he sold guitars for just the cost of the materials. As he became known as a good guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, he only makes about ten guitars a year, so he doesn't earn a lot. In the beginning, he went to music festivals to show his guitars to musicians. He learned how to price his guitars by talking to musicians.

Jonny thinks it's easier for new guitar-makers in the UK now. When he started, people thought only American guitars were good. But now, UK-made guitars are respected. Jonny says learning in a classroom is good, but trying things yourself is important too. He believes you learn a lot by looking at other instruments and trying different things. If you make mistakes, you learn from them. Jonny was self-taught, and he thinks this helped him learn everything.

Text: When English people talk, they often start with the weather. This is a tradition. A famous writer, Dr. Johnson, said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This was true 200 years ago and is still true today. Many people think English people talk about the weather because they find it interesting. But this is not true. 

The American writer Bill Bryson says the English weather is not exciting. There are no big storms like tornadoes or monsoons. The English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman says the weather is interesting because it is always changing. You never know what the weather will be like.

But both Bryson and Paxman miss the point. English people talk about the weather to start a conversation. When someone says, "Nice day, isnâ€™t it?" or "Ooh, isnâ€™t it cold?" they are not really talking about the weather. They are just trying to start a conversation or fill a silence. 

Talking about the weather is like how monkeys groom each other to be friendly. English people use weather talk in three ways: as a greeting, to start a conversation, or to fill a pause when they don't know what else to say. This is why it seems like English people talk about the weather a lot.

Alice Leader was in front of Hadrianâ€™s Wall in Britain. She was telling her class of 12- and 13-year-olds about how amazing it was that the Romans built a wall 120 km long and 5 meters high 1900 years ago. The students were interested because they chose this trip over trips to Spain, Greece, or France. They wanted to know why the wall was built, but Alice felt her answers were not good enough. She could not find a good book about life at the Wall in Roman times, so she decided to write one herself. 

Alice stopped teaching after 31 years and started writing books in 2001. She said teaching was like acting and very tiring, but writing was exciting and less tiring. Her old teaching friends were jealous because she still worked with children through her books. Alice wants her books to be different from other childrenâ€™s books. She thinks many books for teenagers are about bad experiences or are total fantasy like Harry Potter. Her books are different.

Alice liked to teach English and History together. She loved seeing children go from bored to interested and from not understanding to understanding. She started writing because her two sons were leaving home, and her head teacher suggested a writing course. At first, she didnâ€™t want to do it, but she had to send a story to join the course. She quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby. The course students liked her story and said she should publish it.

Alice asked for a year off from teaching to write her first book. Her husband, Zachary Leader, helped her edit the book. He read her chapters and helped make them better. Aliceâ€™s mother-in-law thinks they are competing, but Alice thinks they work well together.

Text: 'To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to have a special race. The race was between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny and his younger brother Ali would race to the same place. Jonny would drive a car on the roads, and Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. 

â€˜Iâ€™m excited,â€™ Jonny said at the start line. â€˜Iâ€™ve never done this before. The roads have beautiful views, and itâ€™s very cold, so Iâ€™ll stay warm in the car.â€™ Alistair was also excited. He wore winter cycling clothes, while Jonny wore jeans and a sweatshirt. Alistair joked, â€˜Iâ€™ve seen Jonny drive before, so Iâ€™m not sure he will make it. I might stop for a cup of tea on the way.â€™

The race started at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and ended at Fleet Moss, the highest road in Yorkshire. It was easy for the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill on his bike. After a quick handshake, they started. Alistair rode his bike up the hill and across the countryside, while Jonny drove the car on the road.

Jonny had a problem right away. A big tractor came onto the road. â€˜Welcome to Yorkshire,â€™ he said to the cameraman in his car. â€˜If Alistair wins, itâ€™s because of this farmer!â€™ After the tractor moved, Jonny continued driving. Alistair struggled with the hill and had to carry his bike. Sheep watched him as he walked with the bike on his shoulders. 

Finally, Alistair reached the top of the hill. He rode fast across the open ground. Jonny had another problem with narrow roads in the villages. He drove slowly through a stream on the road. After the last village, Jonny drove fast to the finish line. 

Neither brother knew where the other was. Jonny drove quickly to Fleet Moss, while Alistair rode across the last field and onto the road. Alistair reached the finish line first. He asked the crowd, â€˜Is he here?â€™ When they said no, he raised his arms and said, â€˜Yes!â€™ A few minutes later, Jonny arrived. â€˜Well done,â€™ Jonny said sadly. â€˜Iâ€™m disappointed.â€™'

Text: 'When you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon, it is very quiet. You bounce the ball on the soft grass. You throw it up to serve and hit it. You hear the sound of your own shot. The grass, the old stadium, the players in white, and the quiet crowd make you feel like you are in a different world. The quiet helps me play better. I try to think only about the game and the point I am playing. When a point is over, there is noise: clapping, cheering, and people shouting my name. I hear them, but it feels far away. I do not think about the 15,000 people watching me or the millions watching on TV. I am playing Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final, the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, told me it was the most important tournament. When I was 14, I told my friends I wanted to play and win there one day. Before 2008, I played and lost to Federer twice. In 2006, I was happy just to be there. Federer beat me easily because I did not believe I could win. In 2007, I lost again and felt very sad. I knew I could have played better. I cried a lot after that loss. Losing hurts more when you have a chance to win. My uncle Toni is a tough coach. He usually does not comfort me, even when I win. But after that loss, he told me not to cry and that there would be more chances. I told him he did not understand, that it was my last chance. I know a sports career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I missed a big one in 2007. But Toni was right. I had another chance in 2008. I learned from my loss in 2007. I was sure I would win this time. The night before the final, I had dinner with family and friends. We did not talk about the match. They knew I was already thinking about it in my mind. Until the match started, I wanted to keep that space in my head for myself.'

Text: 'A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall went to Africa in April 1957. She loved Africa and decided to live there for most of her life. Jane became famous for her work with chimpanzees. In 1963, she became well-known because of articles and TV shows about her research. She wrote many books, including a popular one called "In the Shadow of Man," which is in 47 languages. Jane Goodall is one of the most famous female scientists of the 20th century. She helped us understand chimpanzees better. Before her work, people did not know that chimpanzees eat meat or use tools. They also did not know that chimpanzees have emotions and social systems like humans. Jane's book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is very important for chimpanzee research. Her study in Gombe, Nigeria, is a great scientific achievement. Jane changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves. Even as a child, Jane was curious. When she was five, she hid in a henhouse for five hours to see how hens lay eggs. This curiosity showed she would become a great biologist.'

Shirley Ford is a voice actor. She can speak like a young boy, a tired mother, an old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. People know her voices from children's TV shows and cartoons. She also does voices for work programs about health and safety. Shirley says she just did a voiceover about back injuries and had to learn medical words.

Shirley explains that doing voiceovers is more than just funny voices. You have to make the script interesting for people who can't see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceovers, but they often don't get the job because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.

After school, Shirley studied drama. She sang songs for TV ads sometimes. One day, someone asked her to try a voice for a rabbit in a cartoon. She thought it was funny but tried it and got a big part. Shirley found out she was good at voices and decided to do more voiceover work. In her second film, she played the main character and her brother and mother.

Adult women often do voices for small boys and girls because their voices are lighter. It's also easier than hiring child actors. Shirley learns new voices by watching children's TV. She does many types of voice work, like educational videos and ads for vacuum cleaners. She says it's hard to sound excited about things she doesn't care about, but smiling while talking helps.

The competition for voice work is tough. A good showreel, which is a recording of what you can do, is important. Shirley says it's good to invest in a strong showreel. She got to the top of her job by working hard and not giving up. She suggests going to special workshops for voiceover work. Shirley loves voices and sometimes keeps speaking in a character's voice even after work. Her children are used to her talking in different voices.

Text: 'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because being a cartoonist is a fun job, like being a race car driver. Many people stop dreaming about these jobs and think about more common jobs, like being a lawyer or making car parts. It seems silly to think you can make money by drawing little pictures like the ones in school notebooks. But some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I loved comic strips as a child, drew for school papers, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college. After college, I showed my drawings to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper that wanted cartoons about local news. I drew some ideas, and they bought them. Soon, I was making enough money to live. To be a cartoonist, you donâ€™t need a university degree, much money, or even to draw well. You need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. Being a cartoonist is hard. You should only try if you feel you can't do anything else. Itâ€™s easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and gives time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making money with your art. I have done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I donâ€™t say no to work because you can learn a lot from jobs you donâ€™t really want to do. It helps to be smart, read a lot, and be curious about everything. What about the business side of being a cartoonist? In the past, many cartoonists had regular jobs at newspapers and magazines. But now, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to make and sell your work. Cartoonists with good business skills often do better than very talented artists. Some people worry someone will steal their ideas, even if they have never sold a cartoon. They donâ€™t let others see their work. To protect your work, you can draw a little â€˜câ€™ for â€˜copyright,â€™ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But itâ€™s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone steals a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it can be a lucky break!'

Text: Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house. I decided to throw away an electric guitar. My dad gave it to me for my 16th birthday. It was a black guitar from Japan. I usually keep old things, but I wanted to throw this guitar away. I took it to the rubbish dump. A young man saw me and asked, "Are you really going to throw that away?" I said yes. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. Later, I felt sad about giving it away. 

A few months ago, I got an email from a man named Keith Rushton. He fixes guitars. He said, "I have your electric guitar." The guitar was sold many times after I gave it away. Keith found my name on the guitar and found me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for. He wanted to sell the guitar back to me. I was very happy. Keith's price was fair. 

My dad used to put name stickers on my things, like my guitar. My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar. It was popular in the 1970s. I liked the sound, but I was not good at it. So, I started playing the electric guitar. It was the time of punk music, and you didn't have to play well to be a rock star. 

When I got my guitar back, I remembered my birthday in 1978. My parents gave me the guitar. It felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I picked it up and played it. My fingers remembered the chords. Playing the electric guitar hurt my fingers a bit. 

The electric guitar is not for playing alone. I want to play in a band. My son plays the saxophone. Maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people like me. We could call our band "The Regainers"!

There is a lot of talk about sleep now. I wrote a book called "Insomniac" about people who cannot sleep well. I talked about how not sleeping enough is bad for our minds, bodies, and moods. People who cannot sleep know how important sleep is. Now, more people are talking about sleep, which is good. But what about dreams? We do not hear much about dreams. When we wake up early, we lose the last part of sleep, which is called REM sleep. This is when we dream the most. Good sleepers spend a lot of time in REM sleep. If someone lives 90 years, they spend about six or seven years dreaming. When people do not get enough REM sleep, they have more REM sleep the next night. This shows dreams are important. In 1953, researchers found REM sleep. Many people agreed with Sigmund Freud, a famous psychologist, who said dreams help us understand our minds. But later, researchers found that dreams are more about the brain's physical work. Now, researchers do not agree on many things about dreams. Dreams are important. A study showed that actors, writers, and directors remember and use dreams more than other people. People who like to be creative use their dreams more. Filmmakers, for example, have a strong connection with dreams because movies are like dreams. But everyone, like teachers and software designers, needs to be creative. Dreams help us think in new ways. When people wake up from REM sleep and say what they think about a word, their answers are more original. This is creativity. I write better after dreaming. Even if a dream is hard to remember, it helps me think. Creativity is not just for artists. We all need to think creatively in our lives. This is why we need to dream.

Susie Ray moved from London to a small town by the sea in south-west England twenty years ago. In her studio, you can see the sea and photos of her two daughters, but no paintings. Susie is a famous copyist artist. She can paint like famous artists from the past, such as Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her paintings look so real that even art experts think they are the originals. The real paintings are worth millions, but Susie's copies sell for a few hundred to Â£12,000, depending on how long she works on them. 

Susie has many clients, including galleries and private collectors. Some people buy her paintings to show off, pretending they are real. One famous person likes to say he has a Van Gogh, but it is really a Susie Ray copy. Some people keep the real painting in a bank and hang Susie's copy at home to save on insurance. 

Susie is honest about her work. She signs her name on the back of her paintings. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real thing, and Susie does not do that. She knows people who have done it and got into trouble. Susie is not rich, but she is happy with her work and does not want to risk her reputation.

Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden. She did not earn much money, but it helped her learn to draw accurately. She tells young artists to learn to draw well and study a lot. Susie can draw many things, but she likes French impressionist artists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas the most. 

Some people think modern art is easy, but Susie says it is not. The impressionists painted quickly but carefully, and it is hard to do both. Susie does not paint her own original art because she is a perfectionist. She once tried painting fishing nets, but they looked like photos. Susie is happy with her work and makes a good living from it.

Ellen MacArthur loved the sea and wanted to be the fastest sailor. She started sailing when she was a child. Ellen felt very close to her boats. When she was on land, she missed the ocean and wanted to sail again. She once came second in a big race called the VendÃ©e Globe, where she sailed alone around the world without stopping. 

Ellen showed me her small boat, Kingfisher, where she lived for 94 days. She planned everything carefully, like how much food and kitchen paper she needed. She had freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and medical supplies. Her boat was very important to her because it kept her safe.

Ellen now thinks the world is like a boat. It is small and needs care. She realized this on a trip to South Georgia, an island in the south Atlantic. She saw old whaling stations and thought about how people take too much from the Earth.

Ellen wants to help save the planet. She says we need to stop using things like coal, oil, and gas because they will run out. She talks about re-using things and has visited many factories and power stations. Ellen started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation to teach young people about a better future.

Ellen misses the adventure of sailing, but she thinks helping the planet is more important. She wants to use her voice to make a difference.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old. He wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he does it, he could become very famous. Many young people play on computers and games, but Jordan wants to show them they can do big things too, like climbing mountains or going outside more. 

Jordan's team includes his dad, Paul, and his mom, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero'. Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and another mountain in Antarctica, he will be the youngest to climb the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they are 30 years old. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains.

Some people think it is not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb Everest. They say a young person might be strong but may not have enough experience or emotional strength. The Romeros know people think this way. Paul says they think about the risks but believe their experience will help. He feels confident because Jordan is becoming strong and mature.

Some wonder if Jordan's dad is pushing him too hard. Paul says it is not about him wanting to be famous. They talk to Jordan to make sure he still wants to climb. Jordan says he likes the challenge and focuses on his goal.

Today, many people want to be the youngest or fastest to do something. They write about their adventures online, and people are interested in these records. Jordan needs to share his story to inspire others. This means he has to blog, take photos, and give interviews. He needs to do something big, like climbing Everest.

Paul says if Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, they will stop the project and support him.

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, they are probably not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask them about Brahms, they might not know who he is. I am studying music at university, but my classmates do not know much about classical music either. If you do not know the music, you probably do not have any recordings of it. Not many people go to classical music concerts. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music. Classical music recordings do not sell many copies. 

Why do people not like classical music anymore? Some older people think TV and video games are the reason, but I do not agree. Classical music is not very interesting to most people, especially teenagers. Teenagers buy most of the music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who like classical music, but they are few. I play in an orchestra, but I am not a big fan of classical music. I like many types of music, but I do not listen to much classical music.

Why do teenagers not like classical music? Classical music changes speed and mood a lot, which is hard for us. We like to talk fast, play fast, and think fast. Experts say we cannot pay attention for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical music but perfect for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to. It also talks about things teenagers care about, unlike classical music, which has no words.

The way we listen to music has changed. In the past, families played music together at home. Now, we can find any music online, but we do not often choose classical music. Shops do not play classical music in the background. One of my teachers says more people go to classical concerts now, but not many are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play in many places, but the audience is mostly older people. Teenagers often do not like what their parents like.

Some people say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids like to play it in school orchestras. They practice a lot, but when they relax, they choose pop music instead.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mom's car and looked at Almonside School. "I'll make you sorry I came here," she said to the school. Her mom didn't hear her. Bonnie's mom knew how she felt. Almonside was a strange school with many buildings hidden among trees. It was confusing. Bonnie saw a sign that said "Riding Centre" and got interested. Her mom said, "Headmaster's study. This way." Bonnie followed her mom on a path between trees. Her mom said, "I wish you'd walk beside me," but Bonnie didn't. 

Soon, her mom was talking to the headmaster, and Bonnie waited outside. Bonnie thought, "Why should I just sit here? I'll be in trouble soon anyway." She left and went to the riding centre. There was a nice building for horses and a big place for indoor riding. Bonnie liked horses and treated them with respect. She looked at each horse. 

She found a horse she liked. "Aren't you the best!" she said. The horse was brown with some white. His name was Maverick. Bonnie wanted to ride him. She found a room with riding equipment. It was open. She put a saddle on Maverick and forgot about her mom and the headmaster. 

When she sat on Maverick, she felt like a queen. Her old school called her Queen Bee. She laughed. "You're the best horse I've ever ridden, Maverick," she said. She made him walk and then trot. "If I stay here, we could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The wind felt nice on her face. She knew Maverick trusted her and would jump well.

I have met Cody Simpson before. He is a 15-year-old boy from Australia. Cody is a singer and has many popular songs. But how did he become famous? Cody started playing the guitar when he was six years old. He began writing songs at seven. He also liked swimming and surfing. When he was 13, he put some videos online. These videos changed his life. 

Cody and a friend sang at a school concert. People liked the videos and wanted more. Cody made more videos at home. Many people loved them. Cody was also a good swimmer. He trained with top coaches. But then, music companies wanted to work with him. Cody had to choose: stay in Australia and swim or move to the US and sing. Cody chose to sing. 

It was hard for Cody to decide. He was only 12 or 13 years old. He told his swimming coach and friends he was moving to the US. They were surprised. Cody is a quiet person. He and his family moved to the US. His family helps him but stays out of the spotlight. Cody thinks it is important to have good people around you. 

Sometimes, Cody worries about his family. His little brother is eight years old. He travels a lot and does school on the road. Cody's family supports him and tells him not to worry. Success comes from saying 'yes' to big chances, even if they are scary. Cody is happy to visit new countries and play for many fans. But he knows it will not last forever.

I woke up and looked out my bedroom window at the river. The ice on the river was starting to crack in the morning sun. Last week, I helped the town put sandbags by the river to stop flooding. It was hard work, and my back still hurt. I saw a boy I didn't know trying to walk on the ice near the warm water from the factory. I put on my kayaking wetsuit and checked my pocket for a special silver chain. My grandfather gave it to me from his trip to South America. I also have his diary from that trip, which I read at night.

I went to the kitchen. "Morning, Rex," Mom said with a smile. "You're up early. I'll make brunch after your training. Be careful." "Thanks, Mom," I said. I almost bumped into Grandpa in the hallway. "Watch where you're going!" he shouted. "Where are you going?" "Kayaking," I said. Grandpa often gets angry, but I try to ignore it. He said, "What's the point of training? You didn't win the competition." His words hurt, but I took a deep breath. He went into the bathroom, and Mom gave me a kind smile. "Don't mind him," she said. "He's not himself right now." I used to think Grandpa was a hero. He has photos in National Geographic and medals in his room. I don't go in there anymore. I have my own trophies now, and maybe one day, I'll be in National Geographic too. But I still care about him.

Mom said, "At least he's coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination!" I smiled and said, "It'll be warmer in South America if I find sponsors for my trip." She laughed, and I went outside to the boathouse.

Mum held Jess's arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table was a painting by Grandpa. It was not finished and looked different from his other paintings. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I haven't seen it before. I didn't know he was painting." Jess looked at the picture. There was a big river, but it didn't look real. It was strange and beautiful. There were no animals or people in the picture. It felt right that way. Jess thought about autumn coming after summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded different, like she was excited. Grandpa never named his pictures. Mum turned the picture over and showed Jess the words Grandpa wrote. Jess read them: "River Boy." The words felt important to her, but she didn't know why. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Yes, it's strange," Mum said. "Maybe he will add the boy later. I asked him about it." "Mum! You shouldn't have asked." "I know, but I was curious. It's unusual for him to name a picture. You can guess what he said." Jess knew. Grandpa would say that a painting speaks for itself, like a poem. He would say it's not the artist's job to explain it. Mum laughed. "Something like that. I thought you might know about this painting because you inspire him." "Inspire?" Jess knew the word. Grandpa used it when she watched him paint. He would say the muse wasn't helping him or he needed to be nice to the muse. She thought the muse was a goddess, not a person. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

Text: 'This morning, I did not plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I am not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. Maybe if I tripped with Dadâ€™s knife in my hand, the knife might have cut the carpet. I did not wake up thinking, â€˜Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.â€™ It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but it was too late. This happens to me a lot. I was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It is small, white, with pink and blue flowers, and has tiny glass doors. Gran kept china ornaments in it. I keep shells, fossils, and stones there. I was happy when Gran gave it to me! But it is a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle. It needs to be in a corner. My bedroom is small, like a wedge of cheese, with only two corners. The big bedroom is Mum and Dadâ€™s; the back one is my sister Angelaâ€™s; the one over the garage is my brother Tomâ€™s; and the smallest one is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But Angela is only fifteen, so I will be in my small room for a long time. I donâ€™t mind; I like my cosy room. The roof slopes down, and the window is at floor level. The problem is, there are not enough corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried to put Granâ€™s cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was a little too tall. I thought, if I canâ€™t cut the cabinet, maybe I can cut the carpet. It seemed like a good idea. Dad calls this â€˜lateral thinkingâ€™. He always tells us to â€˜think outside the boxâ€™. That is what I was doing!'

The book 'The Borrowers' is about a family of very small people who live in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly take things from normal-sized people to live. I was asked to make a TV show from the book. I knew it would be hard because people who love the book have strong ideas about it. I used the book's drawings a lot because I didn't want people to say I did it wrong. The author wanted the show to be from the Borrowers' view, not humans', which made filming harder. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so we had to film from far away. The crew had to film from low to show the Borrowers' view, and they wore out many jeans! We never lifted the cameras higher than the Borrowers, except for some shots from above. A big challenge was making the shadows look right when we mixed the small Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We made a special way to do this. After the show was on TV, a famous director, George Lucas, called to ask how we did it. We built the Borrowers' home under the floor with big objects to make the actors look small. It was funny and strange. The actors had to carry big things like giant scissors, and it made everyone laugh. There was a scene where the Borrowers go down a drain. The actors were really scared because they had to go down a tunnel with water hoses. Getting the costumes right was important. The clothes were made from heavy material, so they looked like doll clothes. The main actress couldn't sit or take off her dress because it was sewn on. The main actor's trousers were made from a rug. It was very hot during filming, and the actors didn't like the costumes. Most scenes away from the Borrowers' home were filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen. They had to pretend things were there. I drew 2,000 pictures to show how each scene should look. We didn't have much money, so I worked at night for three months. We worked fast, and once I filmed a scene without film in the camera. But in the end, the show was good and showed the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, but there are no journalists. I wonder how long it will be before people start asking for free tickets to my dad's concerts. "Everything will be fine," I tell her. She kisses her finger and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me to face this new school alone. I wanted this change to get away from my old life. My dad's band is here to record music, and we are staying. I wanted to meet normal kids. Maybe kids with parents who work regular jobs. 

I walk into the school office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I say to the secretary. "Name?" she asks. "Desert McGraw," I reply. She seems confused but types my last name. My dad uses a stage name, so people don't recognize my last name. "What grade?" she asks. "Eleventh," I answer. She prints my schedule and gives it to me. My first class is English Literature. I like English, so that's good. I studied the school map last night, so I know where to go. 

When I get to the classroom, the teacher is calling names. I quietly sit at a desk. The girl next to me smiles and says, "Nice shoes." I look at my fancy shoes and think I should have worn something simpler. "Thanks," I say. The teacher calls my name, "Desert McGraw?" "Here," I reply. The teacher, Ms. Smigla, talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. Then she lets us talk to each other. 

"Why did you move here?" the girl next to me asks. I have many reasons. My dad said we needed a change and this place is good for recording music. But I think he just wants to relax on the beach. "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. "What does he do?" she asks. I know people will find out soon, but for now, I say, "He's an artist." "Cool. I'm Becca," she says. She doesn't seem to care much, which is great.

Text: 'Today, American teenage girls have many things to do. They need to be leaders at school, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in everything. This is what it means to be a teenager in America now. Boys and girls cannot just go to school and be average. They have a lot of pressure. Teenagers have homework, tests, activities after school, jobs, chores at home, and they also try to have a social life. Kristen, a teenager, says people forget how hard it is for teenagers today. Even with all this work, people still think teenagers are lazy and only care about themselves. Kristen says this is not true. She uses her phone to help with her work, not just for fun. Teenagers need to be connected all the time. They use phones and tablets to do homework anywhere. Schoolwork does not stop at school; it needs attention all the time. Many teenagers wake up at 6 or 7 a.m. and go to bed after midnight. They have school, activities, family duties, and homework. They do not get enough sleep. Only 20% of teenagers get the right amount of sleep. Some even fall asleep in school because they are so tired. Lindamarie, another teenager, says she has only 18 hours of free time each week. She uses this time to help others, not just for social media or TV. She likes to volunteer and help her community. In the future, teenagers will keep showing they are not just lazy. They will continue to make a difference in the world before they finish school.'

The Earth to Sky Calculus Club is a group of teenagers from Bishop, a small town in the US near the Sierra Nevada mountains. They have sent over fifty balloons high into the sky, about 35 km up. This is a science project that is also an adventure, which is why many teenagers like it. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were going to send a balloon up to try and see shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere and makes a light trail.
