With 800 meters left, Radcliffe realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes. She had run 41 kilometers very fast and still finished the last part in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the end, she thought she could run even faster. The race director, Dave Bedford, said he didn't think anyone would beat her time soon. Radcliffe thought she could do it again next year, but that didn't happen.

After the race, people wondered how she ran so well with her unusual style. Hartmann worked with her a lot, helping her with the pain from running 250-300 kilometers each week. He said she was very tough and could handle a lot of pain. Hartmann traveled from Ireland to France to help her, and she always wanted to start training right away. She worked very hard, and that made her great.

Radcliffe doesn't know why no one has beaten her record. She trained very hard, but she thinks others are more talented. She thought Mary Keitany might beat her record. Radcliffe says maybe people are racing each other instead of pushing themselves. She always pushed herself to do her best, even when she was winning.

That marathon was the best race of her career. She never ran that fast again, but she inspired many women to start long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, "In Search of Perfection," started, I didn't know if people would like it. At that time, many people were talking about a big change in food in Britain. I thought our show was new and different, but I was still worried. Would people like a show about cooking that also talked about history, memories, and science? I watched the first show feeling both happy and scared. I didn't need to worry. The show was a success and led to many other interesting projects, like a book about my restaurant. Each project feels like a journey, whether it's about the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I wrote more books in a series called "Perfection," each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was real, with travel and meeting new people. "In Search of Total Perfection" is the latest book, where you travel the world to meet amazing people, like a man who makes the best pasta. These people have spent many years trying to make perfect food. Perfection is different for everyone. Choosing which dishes to include in the series was hard, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish wasn't there. But after a long meeting, the TV team and I made a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on feelings, memories, and places. I knew the recipes wouldn't be the best ever, but I wanted to use my skills and knowledge to find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary says perfection means being perfect, but it also means improving through trying new things. The TV series let me explore new foods, people, and places, which was very exciting. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. Some adventures included visiting a factory with the wrong tomatoes and a dairy farm that wasn't good enough to film. I also tried new cooking methods, like hand-milking a cow to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital machine, and almost burning my house while making pizza.

We were still far from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise and stopped in a field. John got out and looked at the engine. He didn't know what to do and started to laugh with Mum. Bea was worried and said, "We can't stay here forever." The field was big with grass and flowers. I agreed with Bea because it was safe to be on her side. We got back in the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. John went to find someone who could fix the van. Mum lay on the grass and asked for a story. I told them about two birds I heard in London. They talked about food, other birds, and the weather. Bea said it was silly because no one understands birds. I felt sad because I thought I did. Mum fell asleep. John came back with three boys who helped push the van to a hotel. Bea stayed in the van, but the boys smiled and waved at her. We went to a cafÃ© near the road. John thought it was expensive, but Mum said we would just have tea. The tea was very sweet. We stayed there all day while John tried to fix the van. When it got dark, Mum made a bed for us outside. John said we needed to be towed to Marrakech. Later, we sat in a truck watching our van being pulled. Bea didn't want to move, so John carried her to the truck. I wondered how we would get home. I thought maybe we could take a boat to London. Then I fell asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel. She talked to two other pianists. One was a man from Tokyo, and the other was a woman from Europe. Lucy didn't hear the woman's name clearly. They were not in the competition like Lucy. They were older than Lucy, about ten years older. They spoke English well and talked about music and travel.

Lucy said, "I think I'm going to Tanglewood this summer." It sounded impressive, but she didn't really want to go. She didn't want to do many things, like concerts and competitions. These events made her miss a lot of school. She studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco instead. Lucy didn't even want to come to the Prague Festival. Only fifteen young pianists from around the world were chosen, and she was one of them. Her dad bought her a necklace to celebrate, and her brother Gus dreamed of going to the festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her to dinner to plan her music. Lucy didn't apply to the festival herself. Her mom did it for her. Her mom said, "I didn't want you to be sad if you didn't get in." Lucy thought her mom just didn't want her to say no.

The man from Tokyo asked, "Tanglewood?" Lucy said, "Yeah." He asked, "How old are you?" Lucy said, "Fifteen." The woman said, "Wow." Lucy didn't want to brag. She just wanted to fit in. The woman left to talk to someone else. The man from Tokyo stayed and asked if Lucy had been to Japan. Lucy said she went once when she was eight.

Then, Lucy's grandfather came and took her to meet other people. He said, "Don't get too friendly with the competition." Lucy said, "They're not the competition." Her grandfather said, "Everyone is the competition." He made her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, but she didn't hear everything.

In the elevator, her grandfather said, "You did well, Lucy. I'm proud of you. This is an important festival, and people know who you are." Lucy liked being important, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young. At school, being a pianist didn't make her special. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't care about her music skills. But at the festival, Lucy felt like she mattered.

Dad said, "It's not good to spend so much time online. You should go out more." I wanted to know what experts think about this. Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends and feel like they belong. They also learn important computer skills. Simon Miles, an expert, says social media is a big part of growing up today. Teenagers use it a lot, not just for quick things like adults do. It's not good or bad; it depends on how you use it.

Jim Matthews, who studies social media, says it's like when our parents went to youth clubs to talk and have fun. Social media helps teenagers find out who they are and learn to get along with others. Professor Keith Davidson, a psychologist, says social media can help teenagers understand themselves better. They can share their favorite music or sports and see different opinions. People who use social media a lot are not as focused on themselves as those who don't.

Professor Andrew Phillips studies young people using social media. He thinks it helps quiet people with special interests find others like them. If you like a special kind of music and only a few people at school like it too, social media can help you find more friends who like the same thing.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, says teenagers can find new interests online and create their own content. They make videos, podcasts, and blogs about what they like. Photo-sharing sites help photographers learn and share pictures. This can help them get jobs in the future because businesses use social media to sell things. If you have many friends on social media, they can be your customers.

Jim Matthews agrees that using social media creatively is good for future jobs. Working with others online to make and share things is an important skill today.

Text: 'When most people think of a family vacation, they don't usually think of a long trip through nine states in the US and a part of Canada. But my parents wanted a different kind of vacation this year. My dad planned a big family trip. He said, "Not enough people do this anymore." My brother and I were not very excited. In June, we packed our car with bags and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was happy but knew I would miss my privacy for two weeks. We started our trip, leaving our big home for a small space in the car. We drove west through Oklahoma. We had some adventures, like almost getting caught in a dust storm. We learned that cows have the right to cross the road first! The next day, we woke up early and drove again. We saw deserts and mountains. We visited the Great Sand Dunes and Pagosa Springs in Colorado. The town smelled like sulfur, which was new for us. We learned that some roads are only for special cars like Jeeps. We saw many wind farms and went to Yellowstone National Park. We saw bears near the road, which was exciting. We stayed in an old hotel with no internet or phone service, but the views were amazing. After a rainstorm in Canada, we drove back home. My parents were right. We didn't need to go far to see amazing things. It was nice to be home, and I didn't fight with my brother during the trip! We took many photos to remember our journey. I will always remember the fun and unexpected moments.'

Rose Frost was 16 years old. She was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was going to be apart for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job in another country, and her mother, Dahlia, would go with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy would finish her last year of school and live at the college. She had a nice room with a kitchen and study area. She also had free Internet and phone. Jeff and Dahlia would still check on Amy.

Rose was moving to her grandmother's house. She only remembered a little about her grandmother from holidays. She never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, Rose's parents were not very happy, but Daisy wanted to know her granddaughter again. Rose did not know why her parents did not like her grandma, but they had a problem in the past. Rose was happy when she last saw her grandma.

Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy liked to meet people and go to events. Rose would get dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips. Rose smiled at the thought. Daisy was not a typical old lady. She went to many social events.

Before moving, Dahlia and Rose talked. Rose was smart and mature. She knew about eating healthy, staying fit, and sleeping well. Rose wanted independence. She wanted to play music loud, invite friends over, and go out without asking every time. She did not want to be told about homework or staying out late. Daisy understood.

Rose's mother gave her a new phone for emergencies. Rose was very happy. They agreed to trust each other. Daisy would trust Rose to make good choices, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too strict. If there was a problem, they would talk about it.

Rose was not a wild child. Her school friends were like her, so her school reports and exam results were good. In five weeks, Rose would start a new school, meet new friends, and start her life again. It was her fourth school in five years, so she was used to it. This was her last time changing schools. For Rose, it was a new start in her life.

Charlotte Grainger says her primary school teacher thought she might write a book one day. Charlotte thought writing a book was a big challenge. When she was 13, she decided to try. Now, her book is going to be published. She told her old teacher, who was surprised. The teacher thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40. Charlotte didnâ€™t want to wait because she thought she could be good at it.

Charlotte is 15 years old, and her book is very good. It has a strong story and lots of action. It doesnâ€™t seem like a teenager wrote it. A person from the book company is with us, but Charlotte doesnâ€™t need help. She is smart and confident but not too confident. Charlotte knows she is young and doesnâ€™t have all the answers. She wanted to ask big questions in her book, like about taking responsibility.

Charlotte thinks books for teenagers often show three types of teenagers: the outsider, the naÃ¯ve one, and the awkward one. She didnâ€™t like this because she thinks not all teenagers are like that. She believes teenagers can know who they are.

Charlotte likes reading fantasy books, but they almost stopped her from writing. She thought she had to write like them to be good. She learned from a book called How Not to Write a Novel that if readers can guess what happens next, the story is not exciting.

Charlotteâ€™s parents are journalists, and her dad knew someone in publishing. This helped her book get read. She knows she was lucky, but she also knows that writers need to be good to succeed. She doesnâ€™t take her success for granted.

Text: "â€˜Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,â€™ said Gareth, our teacher, as we looked down the ski slope. â€˜Now, who wants to go first?â€™ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had done some freestyle ski-jumping before, went first. He skied fast towards the jump and flew up, but something was wrong. We watched closely. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and fell into the snow. â€˜Remember,â€™ Gareth said, â€˜speed can be tricky.â€™ Maybe I wasnâ€™t good at this freestyle skiing. On other ski holidays, I liked practising turns in the snow. I wasnâ€™t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes. I thought it looked fun, but I didnâ€™t know how to do it. My parents decided weâ€™d have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing centre in the US. It had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps with fake snow. Students jumped and landed in foam cubes. After practising inside, students went outside to try for real. â€˜Progress is sure!â€™ the centreâ€™s slogan said. â€˜Before places like this, new ski jumpers just went down the slopes and hoped for the best,â€™ said Gareth. â€˜But remember â€“ if you land on the flat part, youâ€™ll be in trouble.â€™ The â€˜knuckleâ€™ is the flat part before the slope goes down again. Land in the right place, and you keep moving. Land on the flat, and you stop suddenly, which hurts. Thatâ€™s why you need speed. At first, it was hard to go fast towards the jump. My legs wanted to stop, so I landed on the flat part. I didnâ€™t fall, but I felt tired. â€˜You need to control the jump,â€™ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought Iâ€™d hate being inside, but bouncing was fun. Some moves were like ski-jumping, others taught us to know what our body was doing in the air. Gareth talked to us. My â€˜aerial awarenessâ€™ needed work. I only knew what was happening before I jumped and then found myself in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. I had more problems before I landed right. Gareth was happy, and I felt proud. But it didnâ€™t last long. On the last run, I didnâ€™t slow down, jumped, and landed well. Then I saw my skis sliding down the slope without me."

Text: 'Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at a fun park. Your hands are sweaty, and you hold on tight. The ride stops, and you take a deep breath. Then, the rollercoaster goes up slowly. It stops for a moment. Then, it drops fast, and you feel your stomach in the air. You go forward, left, and upside down very quickly. You feel scared and shout. But you wanted to go on the ride, like many other people. Amusement parks with exciting rides are very popular. Many people work to make these rides fun and safe. They are engineers and designers. Making a rollercoaster is hard. It must be fun and safe. It also needs to be new and exciting. Many ideas for rollercoasters were made by John Miller in the early 1900s. I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts said it is about making people feel excited but safe. Rollercoasters need a good story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase. They also need to be the tallest or have the most twists. Professor Walker said that experience and testing are important. Jeff Hornick said you need to like thrills to make good rides. I asked if new technology like virtual reality will change rollercoasters. Walker said it can add to the ride, but the real rollercoaster is still the most important part.'

Miranda Ellington is 25 years old and works as a choreographer. She makes dances for many theatres and dance companies. Sometimes, she still dances too. She likes dancing because it reminds her of how it feels to be a dancer and listen to choreographers. This can be hard and stressful. As a choreographer, she teaches young students. She likes working with them because they are open to new ideas and want to succeed. They listen to feedback, even if it is tough. 

When Miranda works with a new group, she focuses on dance steps and music. Sometimes she does not like the music, but she still tries to make a good dance. If dancers do not like the music, it can be hard, but she finds solutions. She cannot change the music because it is already chosen for big shows. She wishes she could try different music to make rehearsals more fun.

Miranda does not work with just one theatre or school. She likes meeting new people and learning different styles. This helps her not to get stuck doing the same thing all the time.

There was a documentary about ballet dancers and choreographers. Miranda thinks it shows real life in a dance company. It shows how hard dancers work and how much they practice. 

Miranda believes a great dance show has good music, costumes, lighting, and dancers. Everything should work well together. Sometimes, even if the dance is good, bad costumes can ruin it.

Miranda does not want to be known for just one type of dance. She wants to try many things and learn more.

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on TV. I said you can see great things on TV, but why stay at home when there is so much to see and do? This talk gave me an idea for a fun four-day trip and a film to make people turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, and it became the star of the film. I put three wheels and some cables on it and used old seatbelts to pull it. I put my bags on the sofa and slept on it every night, even one night on the beach. Some friends helped me pull the sofa and cheered me on. I have walked a lot in the past, but this was new. It was the longest walk I have done, and it was on main roads. I could stop at a cafÃ© and relax on the sofa with a coffee instead of eating sandwiches on a rock. People often asked me, "Are you doing this for charity or a marathon?" I liked telling them, "No, I just wanted to do it." When someone at work asks about my weekend, I like to say I pulled a sofa 100 miles across southern England. You can watch the film on my website.

Text: 'When I read about swimming trips in the sea around small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be good for me. At the Greek port, the man was surprised when I asked for one ferry ticket because the islands are popular with families. I told him I would join ten others to swim around the islands. He was still a bit confused, but he smiled and let me on the boat. Our group had sent emails before the trip, but we didn't have much time to talk before our first swim. Our guides said a support boat would be with us, and they showed us how to talk to it. We did a short swim to divide into speed groups, then it was time for our first 1.5 km swim. I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and swam in a river, but never in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group. I watched faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first swim, and I was happy when I did it by myself. The next days were the same: jumping in, swimming at a good speed, and stopping to look at the scenery. As the swims got longer, I got faster and enjoyed them more. We didn't need the support boat much. I can't wait to come again next year.'

Being a flight attendant is not easy. But since I started, I have traveled a lot, from the US to Australia. I work with great people, have a lot of free time, and life is never boring. This is a good job for a young person like me! 

When I was a child, I went to a school in another country, away from my family. I flew alone when school started and ended. I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help give out meals to passengers. Some said yes. I remembered this later when I wanted to leave my banking job and find something new.

At the interview for the flight attendant job, there were many young people. Many were accepted. They were smart and wanted to change jobs, like me. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I talked about my strengths and past work, not just that I loved to travel. I got the job!

I think this job is great for anyone. There are many good things about it, but free flights are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard. We say, "no-oneâ€™s finished till everyoneâ€™s finished." It feels like a big family. Even if we donâ€™t see each other all the time, we are still close.

When I am not working, I donâ€™t have to think about work. If I have difficult passengers, which is not often, I know the flight will end soon, and I will not see them again!

Text: 'At the summer camp where I work, I like seeing the children do things they thought they couldn't do. Most children know how to swim and play table tennis before they come here, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel scared, but after we encourage them, they try and reach the top. This makes them feel happy. Some children miss home at the start of the week. It's not the very young ones who miss home the most â€“ it's the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we say they can call home after lunch. Then, when they ask again after dinner, we say it's too late now, call tomorrow. Most children feel okay after a few days, and at the end of the week, they thank us because they had a great time. Sometimes, it's not just the children who feel lonely. Parents often call a lot, asking how their child is doing, which is not needed. Often, the child is busy playing games or doing something else, so we tell the parents to call back later. We also see some children come in expensive new clothes. These children usually argue when we ask them to change into something better for camp, but soon they understand why.'

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show. The actors must also be good musicians. It started in London last year after five years in the USA. In the USA, it won â€˜Best Musicalâ€™ four times! In the UK, it was hard to find enough actors. This is because young actors in the UK can do fewer shows each week than in the USA. So, they needed more actors in the UK. But the director found many talented actors in the UK. They have just won their first â€˜Best Musicalâ€™ award in the UK. The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA. It is full every night because people want to hear the songs. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, â€˜Itâ€™s great that I get paid to play, especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.â€™ Jamie said the young actors are busy. They have school lessons at the theatre every day. He likes the teacher but misses his old school friends. His whole class came to see the show. The theatre has special ticket prices for schools. His class loved the show, and it made Jamie feel good. His parents come when they can, but it is expensive for them. I told Jamie I also play guitar. He gave me a guitar, and we played a song together. I did not know the song, but Jamie helped me. I was happy when I played it right. Jamie is very good at playing, and I wished I could play like him. I was just trying to keep up. I was glad the director was not there to hear my mistakes! The young actors are already musicians. Some play many instruments, but they never played in a band before. They found it easy. Jamie said the hard part was looking natural when they first played together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year. It is worth seeing.'
